CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And thank you for watching FBN:am. Over to Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning. Thank you so much. Good morning everybody, happy Wednesday. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, August 1st. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The race to $1 trillion is on, Apple reporting a big beat for the fiscal third quarter. The stock is on track to open at an all-time record high. Take a look, close to $200 a share, we are breaking down the results. When will it hit $1 trillion in market value?

Plus, renewed trade tensions to report, report this morning said if the White House is looking to raise tariffs on China to 25 percent. The president also doubling down on his tough talk at a rally last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've helped rebuild China, we can't do that anymore. We can't do that anymore and our farmers understand it and our workers understand it, and frankly our companies understand it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The escalating trade threat weighing on market this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading, about 39 points on the Dow Industrials, down three points on the S&P. NASDAQ this morning is up by 12 points.

Investors also waiting on the Fed, the Fed decision, no change is expecting for the Federal Reserve. Today, they will be looking for signals about future interest rate hikes and what the Fed says about the environment rest of the year.

This after gains across the board yesterday in Wall Street, take a look at markets, Dow Industrials picked up 108 points yesterday, one half of one percent. S&P500 was up 13, and the NASDAQ yesterday up 42 points, that was one half of one percent.

Global market this morning look like this, as you can see, down across the board. FT-100 is down 78, that's better than one percent. The CAC Quarante is down just a fraction and the DAX Index is down a third of a percent, that's 42 points lower this morning in Europe.

In Asia overnight mixed performances, the worst performer was China. Shanghai Composite down 1.8 percent as you can see.

Finally coming home, the remains of American heroes killed in the Korean War on their way back now to the United States. A repatriation ceremony held in South Korea overnight as Vice President Mike Pence makes his way to Hawaii for a ceremony there.

A scary scene in Mexico meanwhile, a plane crashes shortly after takeoff with more than 100 people onboard but miraculously no one was killed. We have the very latest on this investigation coming up.

And tackling election interference, Facebook pulled dozens of accounts off the site as the Senate Intelligence Committee gears up for a hearing this morning. The fallout coming up.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO, Managing Partner Mike Murphy. And National Security Analyst, Morgan Ortagus. Good morning.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: $203.45, that is the level that Apple stock has to hit today for it to be $1 trillion company.

BARTIROMO: That's pretty incredible.

ORTAGUS: Wow.

MURPHY: Is it a one-day bet?

MCDOWELL: I bet Kevin Kelly that Apple would reach the $1 trillion market capitalization before Amazon. I could win that bet today.

BARTIROMO: You could win that bet today.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

MURPHY: Very well said.

MCDOWELL: Generally, I don't gamble. I don't bet. So if I offer to take a bet, don't take that bet.

BARTIROMO: Great. Great.

MURPHY: Big focus on Apple this morning.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What about that? Tell us.

MURPHY: I mean, the --

BARTIROMO: Would you buy the stock right here?

MURPHY: I would. You know, I would. And let me tell you why, Apple's trading roughly 15 times earnings and you look at all the other big tech companies, they're trading at 70 times earnings, 30 times earnings.

So Apple is shifting away from a hardware maker or phone company into a more technology services type company. If you put a 30 multiple on Apple, it's trading at about $400 a share. So I think there's a lot of upside.

BARTIROMO: Why is it trading only at 15 or 17 times when all the others are trading at 70? I don't get that.

MURPHY: Because it's being priced as a hardware company, a company that just makes a device which it has been. So if you stop ordering a new phone, theoretically the company would seize to exist so it wouldn't continue to grow.

So although phone sales were only up one percent, their services business is up 31 percent. You could argue it's very cheap at these levels.

BARTIROMO: And it's all about the services revenue, right?

MURPHY: All about the services revenue.

BARTIROMO: That's what everyone's talked about, people driving the stock.

MCDOWELL: It's about that -- it's about that but it's also about your average selling price is going up for the iPhones. That is a critical thing that we'll talk about.

BARTIROMO: And the commodities business, true.

MCDOWELL: Right. The average selling price was $724 a unit which was above analyst expectations, analyst expectations didn't even expected to hit $700 and it looks like the real large phone that's coming out in the fall is going to help that price keep going up and up --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: -- because it's expected to be priced at $1,099.

BARTIROMO: Holy moly.

MCDOWELL: A plus size (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Even more than the 10. All right. Hold that thought because we have that coming up right after this.

Joining the conversation this morning, retired U.S. army, Lieutenant Colonel Allen West is with us this morning. Harvard Law Professor Emeritus Alan Dershowitz is with us this morning, along with Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Also the CEO of Hologic, Stephen McMillan back with us, they make the 3D mammography machines. Plus, Family Medicine Doctor Mikhail Varshavski AKA Dr. Mike with us as well.

Big three hours ahead, don't miss moments of it. And, of course, we hit our top story right now which you've already heard a moment of, earnings front and center for Apple. Apple posted strong results last night.

Earnings per share coming in at $2.34 a share on revenue of $53.27 billion. The company sighting strong demand for iPhones as Apple's raising toward that $1 trillion market capitalization. It is another big day for corporate earnings in fact. We've got ADP, Humana, and Tesla all reporting their quarterly numbers this morning while Apple shares are up three and a half percent right now.

Analysts are expecting Tesla meanwhile to lose money, posting a loss of $2.92 a share on revenue of $3.96 billion. Joining us right now is ARK Invest Analyst, Tasha Keeney. Tasha, good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

TASHA KEENEY, INVEST ANALYST, ARK: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the Apple quarter. We heard Mike's analysis here that it's actually trading at a discount to where competitors are. Your thoughts on the stock and the earnings picture.

KEENEY: You know, I like this comparison of Apple and Tesla. You know, Apple used to be considered a fashion statement before the iPhone was popular. People thought, oh -- you know, people are just buying this for the look.

But really, people are buying it because it was more convenient, it was a better phone. And I think Tesla is the same way. You know, people right now think it might be just a fashion statement, but actually it's a better car, it's a better product. It improves overnight in your garage.

So I think that, you know, people are really missing this long-term story of this competitive advantage that's not going away.

MURPHY: But when you look at Apple and Tesla, I think they're two very different companies because Apple has enough cash to sustain itself for a very long time, very strong balance sheet.

Whereas Tesla, you could argue that they need money although Elon Musk says they don't but they need money and could be in a huge cash crunch in a very short-term. So I think the -- although both innovators, both leaders in their industry but two very different stories when you look at the balance sheet.

KEENEY: I agree with you. And I think -- you know, Elon Musk has said that Tesla might not raise money or doesn't need to raise money, I think Tesla could raise money. And in fact, you know, as investors at ARK Invest, we'd be happy with that.

We just want them to get as many cars in the road as possible because these cars all act like many R&D centers. They gather data, they improve the mapping system and they'll lead the way to autonomous driving.

ORTAGUS: So Tasha, speaking of autonomous driving, Tesla certainly has the capability but Volvo has a very autonomous vehicle and all of the major car companies are coming out with automobiles that have some level of autonomy.

What's the difference between like what Volvo is producing in the F90 and how that's I think that's at least a level two or three on the autonomy scale versus what Tesla's producing? Why does Tesla has the advantage?

KEENEY: So when a Volvo car comes off the lot, the technology that it has is stagnant, it stays that way. Tesla can actually improve the technology of the car through over the air updates. And it's the only automaker with that capability.

Also the only automaker that's actually collecting data off of customer cars to make those updates and to feed its (INAUDIBLE) to improve its software system.

ORTAGUS: That data from the car goes back to Tesla?

KEENEY: Exactly.

ORTAGUS: OK, interesting.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But we have to look forward. And Dagen, Apple CEO Tim Cook warned on the conference call that tariffs are attacks on the consumer. So going forward, are we going to still see this kind of outperformance when you've got tariffs possibly cutting into the margins?

MCDOWELL: That's one of the only real serious hurdles in the short run for China is -- for Apple is related to China and what is going on with the White House, with the Trump Administration and China.

Front page of the Wall Street Journal today which you referenced in the open is that this next step of $200 billion in goods that the U.S. is going to slap tariffs on, originally it was forecast from the White House, it was going to be 10 percent, now they're talking about 25 percent and that will be consumer goods.

Apple makes its iPhones in China, it can't really easily shift production to another nation to avoid that. They're analyze -- Apple is analyzing the impact of the trade fight between China and the United States. But I will add this, there has already been negative press floated in China about Apple.

And, again, it's a communist government, it's centrally planned, there's been one criticism that the iMessage service doesn't block spam enough on CCTV, they jump in and said Apple's app store allows illegal gambling apps. So, again, that's how China can hit these American companies.

They can hit them and China is still critical just sales there. Nine -- one-fifth of sales are to China with a 19 percent increase in that nation were Apple in the most recent quarter.

BARTIROMO: Does this -- does this not come into your model in terms of looking where this company goes?

MURPHY: I think if the tariffs become a thing and if -- then Tim Cook made a statement that they will make a public announcement about it and how it could impact the business. So, yes, you have to factor that in when and if it becomes a thing.

It's not affecting the business right now, the business is doing great. It's hitting on all cylinders really. So I think if you look at the other side, if there are not tariffs, if the tariffs don't negatively impact Apple, where is the stock price at that point? And I think it's much higher.

BARTIROMO: I'm surprised there aren't more phones that look at Apple but aren't Apple in China by the way.

MURPHY: Yes. Well --

BARTIROMO: Why aren't they copying Apple phones like they copy everything else, they probably are.

MURPHY: The local Chinese company Huawei, they are now number one in China, they overtook Samsung so they are doing it. But Apple is still a status symbol and they've built this (INAUDIBLE) where once they're using the Apple product you need the Apple music and you have the Apple cloud.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

MURPHY: So I think that --

BARTIROMO: Very sticky business.

MURPHY: Yes, long run rate for Apple right now.

MCDOWELL: Right. China as a government understands the importance of Apple because all the phones are made in China. So they would be careful about allowing runaway theft of the Apple brand when the -- within the country.

BARTIROMO: The -- you know, talking about two sort of innovative, really 21st century companies, you mentioned comparing it to Tesla. The leadership is very different, isn't that right? I mean, does Elon Musk need to change his leadership style as the company gets bigger?

KEENEY: Yes. You know, it's funny that you say that because if you -- Elon Musk is a character, he's out there. And actually we saw with Steve Jobs, he also was, you know, very aggressive on the competition.

He hopped on one of the earnings calls and went on to rant about android, he said it was his -- you know, his personal vendetta. So I think, you know, Elon Musk is this -- is the star figure. I mean, he's doing these amazing things, he's launching rockets, he's re-landing them.

I think that's what makes Tesla employees willing to work for him and willing to work so hard. So we think that's a big part of Tesla's competitive advantage, is his leadership.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But a lot of employees have left. Like their chief engineering is gone. And, again, there's a difference between being inspirational and being a jerk. And I think to the average person, Steve Jobs was a huge inspiration to them. And he was able to see what they needed before they even knew it themselves.

And quite frankly, historically, Elon Musk has acted like a jerk and that's been one of the problems with people in Silicon Valley, these leaders, they think they are Steve Jobs before they've ever produced something that was nearly as successful as even the iPod.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What was that conference call that he had a couple of months ago when he was upset with the analyst? Because they were asking real questions like, why do you burn so much cash? And will you be able to keep burning cash like that without a money raise?

KEENEY: You know, I'm glad that you brought up that point, on that analyst -- on that earnings call, we were actually happy that he did that because we're long-term investors. And all of those questions were so short-term.

BARTIROMO: So it doesn't bother you that they're burning the cash at this rate?

KEENEY: They're missing the force (INAUDIBLE). You know, again, I think they could do a raise and we just want them to get as many cars on the road as possible and right now their competitive advantage is unrivaled.

They have better battery, technology than anyone out there. And, again, they're the only car that's actually updating after it leaves Tesla.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, good stuff. Tasha, good to see you. Thanks so much.

KEENEY: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Tasha Keeney there. Keep it right here for a special jobs in America coverage of the July jobs report. Also, its Friday morning, 8:00 a.m. Eastern. We got a big jobs number coming out especially after that 4.1 percent GDP report last week.

Meanwhile, we'll take a short break. When we come back, fighting election interference, Facebook is pulling the plug on a coordinated effort to influence November's midterm elections. Who could be behind that campaign? That's next.

And then a miraculous escape, more than 100 people on a plane in Mexico making it out alive after their jetliner crashed and caught fire. What authorities are now saying about what caused that plane to go down. Back in a moment right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. New wildfires, more evacuations hitting California. Nearly 20,000 homes threatened right now. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl, good morning.

CASONE: Good morning Maria. Firefighters now battling a new fire that's erupted in Mendecino, California, that is north of San Francisco. About 60 homes forced to evacuate more than 10,000 acres are now burning.

Meanwhile, the Carr Fire continues to rage. The blaze which claimed the lives of at least six people now considered the sixth most devastating fire in state history. Nearly 900 homes destroyed, entire neighborhoods have been flattened.

Well U.S. workers are getting the biggest claim increase in nearly a decade. New report from the Labor Department says the cost of worker compensation in a form of pay and benefits edged up to 2.8 percent, that's the biggest yearly gain since mid-2008.

The increase due to low unemployment with the jobless rate and an 18-year low. President Trump touted the numbers at a rally in Florida last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Since the election we have added 3.7 million new jobs they would not have believed. We're in the longest positive job growth streak in history, think of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, we're going to see what the Federal Reserve thinks of that when it announces its interest rate decision later today. Of course, the statement's going to be interesting.

Well, struggling MoviePass making some big changes to stay alive. Last week it said it ran out of money, so now it's going to make subscribers pay 50 percent more every month. You're now going to have to pay $14.95 a month for the standard pricing plan, previously it was a flat fee of $9.95 to see multiple movies.

The change taking effect sometime this month. MoviePass has drawn the attention of Elon Musk, a Twitter user asked Musk if he could fix MoviePass. Musk simply said no. Maria, those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: All right Cheryl, thank you so much. Coming up, a coordinated campaign, Facebook is pulling the plug on more plug on more than 30 pages trying to use its platform to influence the midterm elections. Who could be behind the effort? We'll have the story next.

And then a masterpiece, one pizza delivery boy wows his customers by playing Beethoven after delivering their pepperoni pie. His performance goes viral this morning, we're going to take you there and get a closer look. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Beijing in a bind, President Trump last night talking tough on trade promising to rebuild the United States after years of unfair trade practices, watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We've taken the toughest ever actions in response to China's abuse of trade practices. And we're doing very well with China, very well. And I have a lot of respect for China and I have tremendous respect for President Xi of China. But this has been too many years of abuse, $500 billion a year, $500 billion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This comes as some of the administration advisors are urging the president to impose a 25 percent tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods. A significant boost from the original 10 percent proposal in a bid to pressure Beijing into a compromise.

China's top leaders now pledging to keep their economy intact aimed at what they deemed new challenges as the president's tariffs start to bite. Joining me right now is the CEO of Nestle USA, Steve Presley. Steve, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

STEVE PRESLEY, CEO, NESTLE USA: Good morning Maria, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Give us your status check as Nestle obviously a European company, you're overseeing what has been an expansion in the U.S. but have you felt the pressure of these escalating tariffs?

PRESLEY: Yes. Look, for us in Nestle, we believe open trade is the right thing for consumers. And so long-term that's what we believe.

And for us obviously the -- it's better for the consumers long-term f we can find good trade balance between the markets.

BARTIROMO: So when the president was with the E.U. Commissioner Mr. Juncker last week, they said that they were moving toward no tariffs, no subsidies on both Europe and the U.S. Give us a practical understanding of what that means for Nestle and what that would mean in terms of what your price is for your goods whether it's coffee or chocolate or anything else.

PRESLEY: Well, it's -- good you ask that. I think for us the reality is in the U.S., the majority of our businesses manufactured in this country for U.S. consumers every day. We have over 50,000 employees in the -- in the country and over 50 factories. And so for us it has less impact to our business in Nestle U.S. than it does for some of our other competitors.

BARTIROMO: So if we were to see no tariffs then you would -- then you would be exactly where you are today, is that right?

PRESLEY: Materially, yes.

BARTIROMO: Even though there are tariffs right now in place on the European side.

PRESLEY: There are. So I'm speaking specifically for the U.S. business we'd be in the same place today. The majority of our products, the vast majority of our products are manufactured in the U.S. for U.S. consumers.

BARTIROMO: The Trump Administration is implementing a sweeping overhaul of U.S. taxes, obviously he did that earlier this year with a positive impact on large corporations, the tax bill, reduced the corporate tax rate from 35 percent all the way down to 21 percent.

Change the way government taxes companies that will operate internationally as well like Nestle operating more than 400 factories across 85 countries. Tell us about the impact on your business. The administration is now talking about its second tax package in terms of to build on the cuts. What would be the impact?

PRESLEY: Well we think tax reform was a good move by the administration. Overall, it makes the U.S. a more attractive place to invest. You mentioned our recent expansion with our Starbucks deal and we continue to look to invest in the U.S. It's our largest market globally and tax reform helps make this a more attractive market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Tell us about the Starbucks deal, when will that be implement -- when does that get executed?

PRESLEY: Yes, we're very excited about the Starbucks deal. We expect to close by the end of August on the deal and really for us it's about building an incredibly strong coffee portfolio that we think is a leverageable platform for years to come in coffee.

We're the leader in North America now and the largest coffee market. It's aligned with our global pillar which is coffee and we're really excited about bringing just a brand that is meant coffee in the U.S. and pair it with our other really strong brands on coffee in the U.S. between an Nespresso, Nescafe, some other businesses we brought to the portfolio in Chameleon and Blue Bottle. So we think collectively we've just got a great portfolio of coffee to go and win in that market.

BARTIROMO: Well tell us about business right now, what would you say the demand picture looks like in the U.S. today?

PRESLEY: I'd say the demand picture is good. The improving health of the consumer and the economy is good for our industry, right? So food and beverage their categories are up for the first time in a while.

We've seen relatively flat to stable categories for the last few years and as the consumers get healthier and job numbers get better, then the food and beverage category gets better. So overall, the outlook's pretty bright.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting raise prices?

PRESLEY: Yes, great question. I think for us, the first thing we focus on is making sure we really look to removing whatever inefficiencies we've had in the business and try not to make sure we pass any of those on the consumers.

We're so consumer focused at delivering great value for our products for them every day, like that's our first step. The reality is the industry hasn't had inflation for the last five years. It's been relatively stable. And so I think some form of pricing will return to the market, I do think it's good for us, it's good for our customers. And the healthy economy and a healthy consumer helps make that possible.

BARTIROMO: And is it fair to say that if you were to see higher retaliatory tariffs, once you sellout to Europe, I know it's produced in the U.S. and it's largely for us consumption. But if you were to see tariffs, does that push you even further to raise prices? Would you be forced to raise prices should you have the tariffs to deal with?

PRESLEY: Yes, I go back to -- we believe that open trade is the right answer in a period. And so I think that's the best long-term hope that we can get t open trade.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about jobs, bringing jobs back to America. Yesterday you celebrated the grand opening of your new U.S. headquarters in Virginia. Pretty significant milestone in the 152-year history of the company.

But even as established Nestle is, you've continued to adapt to future demands through innovation. Tell us about the new plan.

PRESLEY: Yes, absolutely. I think more than just announcing an opening of new headquarters here in Virginia. It's about, you know, relocations are great catalyst that we can inject into the business to transform it in a -- in a huge way and it's been a great lever for us moving across country, resetting the expectation, resetting the culture and driving this culture of innovation in the market.

And we're really excited about the opportunity, we've had a great partnership with the State of Virginia and the local development here and we're looking forward to what being on the East Coast will bring for us.

The reality is for us 80 percent of the consumers, 80 percent of our customers are on this part of the country. So it brings us closer to our consumers and our customers which I think makes us better for the future.

BARTIROMO: So are there new jobs that you will be bringing here as a result of this new plant?

PRESLEY: Absolutely. We continue to grow in the U.S. and so in -- we'll have almost 2,000 employees in the State of Virginia between our corporate headquarters and our two factories. And so there'll be new jobs absolutely as we continue to look to grow our business in the U.S.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Steve2, we'll be watching. Thanks so much.

PRESLEY: Thank you so much Maria, appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Steve Presley, the CEO of Nestle. Coming up, heading home at last. The remains of dozens of U.S. service members killed in the Korean war are now making their way to Hawaii, we've got the very latest coming up as Vice President Mike Pence meets them there.

Then table for two, one joint -- pizza joint getting creative with a little table that comes inside pizza boxes. We'll tell you which chain is rolling out the tiny patio set, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us this morning, happy Wednesday. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, August 1st, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

The U.S. still locked in trade negotiations with China, but a new report suggests that the Trump administration is ready to impose steeper tariffs on good (INAUDIBLE) President Trump reaffirms his position on the trade situation at a rally last night in Florida.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Now that we have the best economy in the history of our country, this is the time to straighten out the worst trade deals ever made by any country on earth, they are the worst.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Futures indicating a mixed showing at the start of trading this morning, Dow Industrials down about 20 points right now, the NASDAQ is up 20 points. This after the market closed higher yesterday after strong earnings from industrials, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 108 points, yesterday, almost one-half of one percent.

S&P was also up one-half a percent, as was the NASDAQ with the 42-point move yesterday. In Europe this morning, take a look at the markets, and we are seeing selling going on, FT 100 down almost one percent, that's 76 points lower, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up a fraction, but the DAX Index is lower by a fraction, 10 points lower in Germany.

The markets finishing mixed, in Asia last night, Shanghai composite, the big loser, down almost two percent in China.

Miracle in Mexico, a plane crash left 85 people injured, but no fatalities, out of the 103 passengers on board, we have a full report coming up.

The earnings bonanza continues this week, plenty of companies reporting before the opening bell, this morning, including Auto Nation, Chesapeake Energy, PSEG and Caesars. So far, the second quarter earnings have been very strong. We'll bring you those numbers as soon as they come in.

We've also got Tesla to reporting after the close tonight, the company hit by uncertainty after Elon Musk's frequent tweeting, among other things, the stock is up one-half of one percent, as company's analysts continue to say, company's keeps burning cash, stock is right under 300 right now.

It might just be too good to be true, a new diet says you can lose weight, eating only steak and burgers. Yes, we're going to chew on the fat on that one, coming up. Plus, a family ordered a pizza and wind up getting a concert to go with it.

Check this out, the 18-year-old self-taught piano prodigy who delivers pizzas. That would be Beethoven and you'll have to hear it to believe it. We're going to bring you that, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning, but first, our top story this half an hour at 6:33 on the East Coast, this social media election interference continues, Facebook, this morning, claiming they've suspended 32 accounts that have engaged in what they are calling coordinated unauthentic behavior, which served to stokes political tensions ahead of the 2018 midterms.

The company's COO, Sheryl Sandberg, explains it here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, COO OF FACEBOOK: This kind of behavior is not allowed on Facebook because we don't want organizations or individuals creating networks of account that mislead people about who they are or what they are doing.

Everyone who works in securities knows security in arms race. We're glad that we were able to find this. We always know that, you know, our adversaries are going to get better and we're going to have to get better.

Also, in investors' radar today, the Federal Reserve is not expected to raise interest rates this afternoon but we are hearing from the Fed after a two-day meeting and we will hear what they say about the future in terms of the interest rate -- the interest rates to come. Tougher tariffs to come as well with the U.S. locked in trade negotiations with China. A new report this morning suggests that the Trump administration could more than double tariffs on certain goods from China.

Futures this morning look like this, after the ADP number, it was pretty stable, we did see markets come off the lows but, as you can see, we are still looking at a decline of 30 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, 15 points higher on the NASDAQ this morning, and S&P 500 is flat. In Europe, this morning, the markets finished -- are trading lower, the FT- 100 is down 91 points, that's better than one percent lower. The DAX Index in Germany is down two-thirds of one percent, and the CAC Quarante in Paris is down a fraction. The markets finished mixed in Asia last night, the worst performer was China, down 1.8 percent.

Facebook is in the hot seat once again, an open-hearing today on Capitol Hill, will look into election meddling through social media. We have the details of who will testify, this morning. At a cybersecurity summit yesterday, Vice President Mike Pence underscored the administration's commitment to keeping our elections safe.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: And I can assure you our administration will continue to take strong action. We've already done more than any administration in American history to preserve the integrity of the ballot box, and we've just begun.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The earnings trade, meanwhile, continues, all eyes on Tesla this afternoon. The company will reportedly invest $5 billion to build a factory in China. It is the race to a trillion dollars, meanwhile, Apple third-quarter report beating expectations last night, putting the stock on track for a record high opening this morning. It is going to open at an all-time high. If it hits $203 a share on Apple, that would be $1 trillion market value. This is the premarket of Tesla, let's take a look at premarket of Apple, and as you can see, the stock is up 4-1/3 percent. If it hits $203.40 that will be $1 trillion in market value for Apple, the first company to do so. A bit of trouble for Bitcoin, additional currency taking a bit of a tumble on Tuesday. We'll tell you if Bitcoin is worth the money, it's at 7,571 right now.

But first, our top story this half an hour, and that is fighting election interference, Facebook now pulling plug on 32 accounts it says engaged in coordinated political misinformation efforts ahead of November's midterm elections.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, COO, FACEBOOK: This kind of behavior is not allowed on Facebook because we don't want organizations or individuals creating networks of accounts that mislead people about who they are or what they are doing. Everyone who works in security knows that security is an arms race. We're glad that we were able to find this. We always know that, you know, our adversaries are going to get better and we're going to have to get better.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This comes as an open senate hearing is set for this morning on social media election interference, Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg herself along with Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey will both testify. They are headed to Capitol Hill this fall to testify in front of that same committee. Joining us right now to weigh in is Harvard Law professor emeritus and author of the book "Trumped Up: Criminalization of Political Endangers Democracy" Alan Dershowitz. Alan, good to see you, as always, thanks so much for being here.

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, PROFESSOR EMERITUS, HARVARD LAW: Well, thank you so much. You know, my new book is "The Case Against Impeaching Trump." "Trumped Up's" my old book so thank you for mentioning it.

BARTIROMO: Well, you've got -- you've written a number of books, "The Case Against Impeaching Trump" was your most recent. And then, you took a look at election interference as well. I want to ask you about that because is there anything you think can be done to regulate this kind of interference?

DERSHOWITZ: Oh, absolutely. That's why from day one, I said we don't need a special counsel. We need a nonpartisan expert commission like the 9/11 commission to look into the entire issue of interference with our elections. Remember, what's going on with Facebook isn't criminal, so Mueller has no jurisdiction over it, but it's very serious. The indictments now in the southern district of New York against lobbyists, have nothing to do with Russian interference, but it's very serious. We don't need a special counsel, we need experts looking into this, and figuring out how to make sure that foreign governments don't interfere with our elections.

There is a possibility of regulation consistent with the First Amendment, but it's difficult and will require a kind of nuanced approach. So, the worst approach is kind of the blunderbuss approach of a special prosecutor behind closed doors, and the best approach is what Great Britain, and Israel, and other countries do, set up royal commissions to investigate the problem and come up with solutions that are broad-based, that's what we need to do with Facebook.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's not just this issue that brings these social media executives to Washington. It's also the fact that Congress is saying that they are censoring conservative ideas. Kevin McCarthy, the majority leader, has been out aggressively saying, look, I'm noticing that you are actually editing out or censoring conservative ideas. We'll see what comes out of this. Any way to regulate any of this?

DERSHOWITZ: There is a way of regulating it. Remember that these enormous organizations, like Facebook and Google, are almost quasi-governmental. They have such fantastic power and can influence that --

BARTIROMO: Lot of influence, yes.

DERSHOWITZ: A lot of influence. First of all, it ought to start with self-regulation, but there has to be the possibility of laws and rules being enacted consistent with the First Amendment. Congress has to pass the laws but it's not the right institution to get the information, because it's so partisan. Having a nonpartisan expert commission, that's what we did after 9/11. We learned so much from that commission, we passed good laws, good regulations, and we haven't had another 9/11. What we're worried about is we're going to have another 2016 in 2018. We're seeing that there are still efforts to interfere with our elections, we have to stop that, and we have to do it aggressively and prospectively.

BARTIROMO: Let me switchgears and ask you about judicial watch now obtaining new e-mails that it says revealed that FBI Agent Peter Strzok insisted on retaining his security clearance before moving to special counsel Robert Mueller's team. How significant do you see this? I mean, he's had this security clearance, even as this entire investigation has gone on into his performance.

DERSHOWITZ: But he should have recused himself -- he should have accused himself -- recused himself from day one. He knew before anybody else knew what his biases were? That he was out to stop the election of Donald Trump, that he needed an insurance policy against doing that. When you have somebody with those attitudes, those aren't just political preferences, those are goals, illegal improper goals, trying to influence the election, putting a thumb of FBI agents on the scale of the elections. He should have recused himself, he should never, ever have been allowed to remain in the FBI, while he himself was being investigated in this way. This is a real problem, a real issue, and I don't think it's being addressed sufficiently.

BARTIROMO: Alan, where do you think this goes, Peter Strzok, Andrew McCabe, all of this abuse of power that we saw at the top, very top of the FBI during the 2016 election.

DERSHOWITZ: Well, the one thing it doesn't happen -- it doesn't go into a Mueller report. Mueller is going to try to protect these guys. That's why, again, the I.G., the Inspector General's report was objective, and what we needed was a nonpartisan expert commission that could look into Strzok. We're not going to hear much about these influences when we see the Mueller report because Mueller has an interest in creating an illusion of objectivity around his investigation. And the last thing he wants to do is expose the kind of subjectivity that he himself allowed in the investigation by not having Strzok recuse himself. Now, to his credit, Mueller did take Strzok out of the investigation, as soon as he learned about the facts, but that was way late into the game, Strzok should have recused himself on his -- on his own, initially.

BARTIROMO: Way late. And I think -- it sounds like what it -- what that would be would be exactly that, an illusion, and not actually objectivity.

Meanwhile, speaking of --

DERSHOWITZ: Well, we'll wait and see.

BARTIROMO: -- Robert Mueller, I mean, there was a report recently that he wants to give Tony Podesta, a former lobbyist, immunity if he gives some information about Paul Manafort. Now, we know that the former lobbyist Tony Podesta and former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig are reportedly under investigation by prosecutors in New York after a referral from the special counsel Mueller's office. CNN first reported the probe. Your reaction to this?

DERSHOWITZ: Well, these are good people. And whether they did anything wrong should be determined, but again, it shows we didn't need a special counsel. The special counsel isn't investigating these guys. The case is in the southern district of New York. Every one of these cases could have been handled by a U.S. Attorney's office. Why did we have to spend so many millions of dollars and bring on additional staff, it's going to end up only in a report and some low-hanging fruit indictments.

And the way in which Mueller is proceeding, trying to squeeze Manafort, trying to get him to testify against Trump, even Judge Ellis who's presiding over the trial, says, this trial is not about Manafort. It's about trying to get Manafort to sing or compose about Donald Trump and other higher-ups. You know, I used to teach my students in first year, if you're going to commit a crime in America, commit it with someone more important than you are so you can turn them in, they can't turn you in. That's the way the Mueller probe is operating, squeezing people at the low- end to try to get people at the high-end, and what you get often in that situation is false testimony, composing rather than just singing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But it's also, like, a really good way to muddy the waters because most Americans out there watching this, don't realize that all of these charges against Paul Manafort are from years ago and have nothing to do with the Trump campaign.

DERSHOWITZ: That's right. And the goal, however, is to get him to have to make a choice, between dying in prison, or testifying against his former associates. And most people prefer to testify than die in prison, even if it means exaggerating stories and making up stories. That's why Judge Ellis was so critical of the prosecution. He didn't throw it out because there was no legal basis in his view, but he was very critical of the motivations of the prosecutor in going after Manafort in this way, and we should all be critical of that. And every civil libertarian should be concerned that this technique can be used against you, your loved ones, people you know, people on your side of the political spectrum.

BARTIROMO: Any expectation in terms of when the Mueller investigation comes to close, real quick?

DERSHOWITZ: Well, I think it either has to end very quickly before the midterms or it has to wait until after the midterms. The worst thing would be to release a report within a month of the midterm elections.

BARTIROMO: Right. Sure. Alan, good to see you this morning, as always.

DERSHOWITZ: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much, Alan Dershowitz. And your new book, "The Case Against Impeaching Trump" is available everywhere, and there it is. Alan Dershowitz.

Coming up, the backlash against democratic socialism, Stuart Varney weighs in on that, coming up next. And then, the race to $1 trillion, details as Apple stock is on track for a record high opening this morning, will it hit $1 trillion at market value today? Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Apple delivers its best ever revenue for the June quarter, typically the weakest quarter of all. Adam Shapiro on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with those details. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. And their guidance for the next quarter, 60 to 62 billion in revenue, so investors are very happy. But take a look at what's going on with just smartphone and iPhone sales, Apple reported they sold 41.3 million iPhones in the last quarter. That was flat, but the average sale price was much better than people had expected. So, that's one of the reasons they're doing so well.

But then they faced competition, Huawei out of China, Huawei sold in the quarter 54 million units. They are now the second largest supplier of smartphones in the world. They've got a market share of 50.8 percent. Samsung is number one, 20.9 percent. Apple has fallen to third with 12.1 percent. But Apple is still rocking the boat and could hit that trillion- dollar market capitalization perhaps today. The share price that they've got to hit to do that is somewhere around $203.45 a share, so we're going to keep an eye on that for each day.

Also, we're going to keep an eye on Tesla. Tesla reporting after the bell, expected to report a loss of $2.92 but revenue is expected to jump by more than 40 percent to $3.92 billion up from 2.79 billion a year ago. The other thing is that Tesla has announced they are planning to build a factory in China, $5 billion. And another thing we're going to watch with Tesla, the numbers on production for Model 3, 28,578 in the second quarter. They are shipping something like 11,000 Model 3 units, now that they're producing 5,000 a week. The other thing, Tesla is going to be big for everybody, you know, something, Maria, my brother has a Tesla, says it's the best car he's ever owned, but to put in perspective, this is a guy who used to own a Chevy Cavalier and a Honda Civic. So, I'm just saying.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Important analogy there. Adam, thank you. Adam Shapiro. Switching gears, to the big cost of big government, a new study says that Bernie Sanders' Medicare For All Plan would actually cost a whopping $32.6 trillion over 10 years. The news coming as one city north of the border, Ontario, is now scrapping a plan to provide basic guaranteed income. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in here. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Please tell Adam that I still drive a Chrysler Town & Country. OK, well, let's get that out of the way. Look, two of the mainstay policies suggested by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders, the socialist wing of the Democrat Party. Two of the main standby-ers are, as you mentioned, Maria, this Medicare For All $32 trillion over 10 years. And this guaranteed minimum income, and that program, a pilot program that's just been abandoned by the people in Ontario, Canada.

Those are two mainstay policies of this new socialist wing of the Democrat Party, and those two policies are in shambles. They're abandoning this idea of a guaranteed minimum income, it's not sustainable, you can't afford it. And you certainly can't afford $32 trillion, as a way of getting you Medicare For All for 10 years. So, I think their policies are collapsing. If they really wanted to help more people, just look towards capitalism and the Trump growth agenda. We have wages now rising at the fastest pace in many, many years. And in fact, their wages are rising 25 percent faster under Trump than they were under Obama. The economy is expanding at a four percent growth rate, we just got 219,000 new private sector jobs -- capitalism is supplying the goodies for more people and socialism is failing. I just wish that the millennials could see that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's pretty incredible that now we're debating whether or not socialism works.

VARNEY: Dear Lord, I'm a refugee from socialism for heaven's sake. You want to ask my opinion? Well, you're going to get it.

BARTIROMO: All right, Stu, I know we'll see you in a few minutes, 10 minutes, then you'll have a lot more on that. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA, join Stuart. First though, getting into the cryptocraze, you break down the latest on Bitcoin as the digital currency dropped seven percent overnight, that's next. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Bitcoin tumbling again, the cryptocurrency dropped seven percent over the last 24 hours triggering fears of bear market, and that will continue for digital currencies. Joining us right now is Perianne Boring, she is the Chamber of Digital Commerce Founder and President. Perianne, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

PERIANNE BORING, FOUND & PRESIDENT, CHAMBER OF DIGITAL COMMERCE: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: So, it's been a wild ride for Bitcoin. Do you think you just need a strong stomach for this? Is this something we should just get used to?

BORING: Yes, you definitely need a strong stomach to operate in this space. You know, if you look at the price of Bitcoin on a day-to-day basis, it does seem to be volatile and that's one of the biggest criticisms people have of this digital currency. But if you're able to zoom out and look at this year-over-year, the price of Bitcoin on August 1, 2017 was hovering around $2700. So, over the past year, Bitcoin has grown about 175 percent. So, Bitcoin is not really -- the price of Bitcoin is not the best indicator of the innovation and the success in the ecosystem. I would encourage you to look at other stats like jobs created, projects underway, new companies, companies going public, fund-raising in this space. There's a lot of other ways to look at and measure the success of Blockchain.

MURPHY: Hey, Perianne, this is Mike Murphy. You know, I see that, you know, your Twitter handle is PerianneDC, so, you know, I wonder if the government is ever going to get involved in the whether it'd be Bitcoin or Blockchain or somehow, regulating this entire industry, how do you see that?

BORING: Well, the Chamber of Digital Commerce, we are the world's largest trade association that's representing the Blockchain technology industry. We're headquartered in Washington, D.C., we're still the only trade association in D.C. that's focused on Blockchain. And what I can tell you is that from a government and regulatory affairs' perspective, there is a lot underway and there are many different government agencies that are looking to regulate this technology, we're doing a lot of work with CFTC, a lot of work with the SEC, a lot of work with the consumer regulators. And there's been quite a bit of activity on Capitol Hill, and we even have a Congressional Blockchain Caucus. So, despite what some people may think, that this is the Wild West or that it's completely unregulated, this is a heavily-regulated space.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching that. Perianne, good to have you on the program, thanks so much.

BORING: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Perianne Boring there. We'll be right back with some final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from this all-star panel, Morgan Ortagus.

ORTAGUS: I think what Vice President Pence said yesterday about calling out America's enemies on cybersecurity is the first time an American official has gone on record to say we're going to be offensive, and it's a really important policy change.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Mike Murphy?

MURPHY: Let's watch Apple today. I think it'd be very interesting to see how they do and if they get to 203.

BARTIROMO: And a hundred -- and $1 trillion in value, Dagen's bet.

MURPHY: $1 trillion.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Always focus on the stocks and the people who are underappreciated, because they surprise you, just like Apple.

MURPHY: Like it.

BARTIROMO: Great. That'll do it for us. Have a great day, everybody. Dagen McDowell, Mike Murphy, Morgan Ortagus, we'll see you soon. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Mr. Trump plays hardball on trade. Instead of 10 percent tariffs on Chinese products coming here.

END

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, June 7.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets this morning are higher, take a look. But that was the high of the morning, actually. Futures indicating a gain of about 56 points on the Dow Industrials; the S&P and Nasdaq are up but just barely, 3 points higher on the S&P. This after the Nasdaq and the Russell 2000 indexes closed at new highs again yesterday. The Dow and the S&P 500 finished at their highest levels in three months.

In Europe this morning, mixed performances, take a look. It was a rough start for London this morning. Trading on the London stock exchange was delayed this morning due to a technical issue. The FT 100 is now up just seven points. The CAC 40 is up a fraction, a third of a percent and the DAX index is also higher by a fraction in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly higher, take a look, with the exception of China which was down a fraction.

Trade tensions -- Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe headed to the White House today ahead of the G-7 meeting this weekend. President Trump at odds with the other six nations in the G-7 going into the summit over the tariff and trade policy out of this White House.

The administration's top official, Larry Kudlow, says this is not a major fight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: I regard this as much like a family quarrel. I'm always the optimist. President Trump is very clear with respect to his trade reform efforts that we will do what is necessary to protect the United States, its businesses and its workforce.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest on trade coming up.

Plus, a high stakes meeting on f Capitol Hill -- Republican lawmakers coming together to try to hammer out a deal on immigration. It comes amid a startling new report on illegal border crossings -- 50,000 people were arrested just last month.

An unbelievable scene in Wyoming to show you -- a powerful tornado touching down in Wyoming. We've got the very latest. Look at those pictures. Wow.

Meanwhile soaring oil prices set to cost you, airlines are now raising the price of tickets. The details coming up.

And a new twist on bridal bouquets, a pizza parlor now offering arrangements made of pizza. But how do you throw it?

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to talk all about it: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Rosecliff Capital CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy, and the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman. Who would want to catch it if it's all pizza?

AUTH: Yes, all this data has enormous value. And it's not showing up on the balance sheets, they're already been expensed and in fact the acquisition of it hasn't been. So, you know, if you look on a cash flow basis, these companies are generating enormous amounts of cash flow.

MURPHY: How much harder is your job right now? Because the velocity of change, with new technology coming out, you know, you have a company going from a start-up, early stage company to a multibillion dollar company in a couple of years. Does that make your job and analyzing and valuing these companies that much harder?

AUTH: I think in general investing in stocks has become more and more difficult. At the same time, more and more investors have just gone passive and that's what creates the great opportunity for the active manager and active managers have now been outperforming the last 12 to 18 months. There's so much money in the market that just -- is blindly investing. In some ways, it makes our job a little bit easier in effect. But yes, I mean, is the complexity high? That's what you're exploring on the show every morning. It's gotten more and more complex.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

AUTH: It is a complex world.

MCDOWELL: But even looking back 10 years, are investors still shaken from the financial crisis and overinvested in fixed income, thinking that fixed income, particularly treasuries -- longer term treasuries are some sort of haven, is that the real concern here?

AUTH: Well, I think --

MCDOWELL: Again, we're staring at a bear market for something, right?

AUTH: Right.

MCDOWELL: It's either, it's going to be equities or --

AUTH: I mean, you're half full, half empty. But I would say that the half full element here and one of our thesis for what we call the secular bull. We think we're in this long cycle secular bull is just that, the base of this expansion is the worst economic crisis since really the great depression and every economic actor out there has been negatively affected by this and they all think sooner or later it's going to roll over. Even the regulators. So they've been very kind to this market as a result. So when everyone's expecting something to happen, that's usually doesn't happen. And that's why stocks we think are still undervalued. Is there a bubble in bonds? We're not a believer of that. We think bond yields are low for a reason and we think they're going to grind higher but we only anticipate -- and certainly if we had a big selloff in bonds, that would hurt equities for sure.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you this, the Federal Reserve meeting next week, you're expecting the Fed to raise interest rates?

AUTH: Well, me and everyone else.

BARTIROMO: And everybody else?

AUTH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: OK. Let's just talk about this for a second, during the break we were talking about and noticing some of this price increases, the price of coffee, Starbucks coffee's going up, airline tickets are going up. What else did we say?

MUROHY: Gas.

BARTIROMO: Gasoline prices are going up. Is inflation an issue? How does the Fed deal with that? And what does the markets do as rates starts going higher?

AUTH: So, some things are going up. But there's a lot of stuff not going up. Price of diapers isn't going up. Most staples the prices are not going up.

BARTIROMO: OK.

AUTH: But there's not a lot of pricing power. And you've got the Amazon effect out there, literally with the Gatling gun on top of the mountain top, waiting for anyone to volunteer there here (INAUDIBLE).

MCDOWELL: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: You're right -- you're right.

MCDOWELL: But I'll throw it at you this way. Maybe consumers aren't getting those price increases passed along, that inflation, but it is hitting businesses. Steel prices even before these tariffs go into effect are up 40 percent in the United States year-to-date or were through the end of last week, even more year over year. You have freight costs going up and Cisco, the food company is saying our costs have gone up. We can't pass them under our customers. That hits profit margins. So, is that a concern if you own stocks?

AUTH: Yes, Dagen, we're about to produce a 20 percent year over year quarterly gains in earnings in the upcoming quarter. So yes, cost pressures are affecting some companies and active investors like us, we're very carefully watching which companies don't have enough pricing power or aren't. But there's other ways to offset commodity price increases as you get productivity. You get a corporate tax cut and maybe you use some of that money to pay your workers a little --

BARTIROMO: What about the trade issue? Are you worried about the trade issue, aluminum and steel tariffs, China fight?

AUTH: No. We're trying to get free and fair trade. I mean, you've been talking about this on the show. But we just see that as a powerful negotiation. The president has most of the cards. He's a very good negotiator. And you go into China, the good cops go in there, Kudlow and - -

BARTIROMO: Mnuchin.

AUTH: Mnuchin, right? And they say look, here's the deal. You guys are shipping $500 billion to us a year. We're shipping you 120. We want that number to change. You've got to take down some of your barriers so we can ship more to you. Give us $200 billion or the bad cops are going to be over here, Navarro, etcetera. That's what's going on.

BARTIROMO: Right, you know what? I'm so glad you're here. Because this was the top of our show. This was the first words we said. Dagen brought this up at the top of the show saying, why we're all worried about all this trade stuff and look at the markets new record highs. This is why. Stephen Auth just told us the sentiments of Wall Street.

AUTH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You're not buying it. You think this is all a negotiation. You just want a better trade deal.

AUTH: And you know, a month ago we were talking about do the Chinese cheat or not? Now we're talking about how much is it? You know, we're up to $80 billion, right?

BARTIROMO: Right.

AUTH: Well OK, that's not going to work. But we'll carry, the bid ask is now 8200. I couldn't find a number.

BARTIROMO: Well, the last time I check, $300 billion cost, to the theft of intellectual property a year?

FREEMAN: You're saying basically you think these larger problems are going to be pushed aside. I don't think this is progress that the government says we're now going to set numbers for imports and exports. Is it?

AUTH: Look, to me the press is hysterical about this and if you think about it, all the president wants is free and fair trade. The tariffs is a cajole he's using to negotiate better terms. BARTIROMO: That's right.

AUTH: The rest of the world, we're dealing with an entitlement here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

AUTH: Even our so-called allies in Europe.

BARTIROMO: Right.

AUTH: We rebuilt the world after World War II. We gave them all these deals. And now we're saying end of the entitlements.

BARTIROMO: And yesterday Kudlow called the tariffs a tool. There you go.

AUTH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Stephen, good to see you.

AUTH: Likewise.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Stephen Auth joining us, Federated Investors.

Coming up, get ready to pay more for your coffee. You just heard it. Starbucks is raising prices again. We'll tell you how much. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: welcome back. Starbucks hiking the cost of your morning cup of coffee again. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: OK, this is going to get expensive, Maria. Starbucks fans are going to have to dig a bit deeper for the cup of Joe in the morning. The company raising prices between $00.10 and $00.20 on all sizes of its brewed coffee in most of its stores here in the U.S. Starbucks blaming the move on the nine percent increase in operating expenses for the first half of its fiscal year. That's compared to last year. Starbucks shares are down less than one percent so far this year.

Well, Jessica Alba's Honest Company receiving a fresh round of funding. The company is getting a $200 million investment from private equity firm L Catterton. The Honest says, that the new investment is going to help expand its business globally, increase product supply and funds of innovation. The company has not disclosed the size of the stake that L Catterton is actually going to receive in all of this.

Well, bargain hunters can now grab a fancy bottle of wine at Wal-Mart. The company trying to appeal to more upscale tastes, launching its own wine label called Wine Makers Selection. Customers are going to be able to buy 10 fine wines from California, France and Italy. Retailing for about $11.00 a bottle. The retailer says the wine will be higher quality than other brands of wine that it actually currently sells. This puts them of course in direct competition with their rival Costco. Costco's got its own private wine label. Shares of Wal-Mart down 14 percent this year. Costco shares are up six percent.

And then I'm so excited about this, Bradley Cooper and Lady Gaga are teaming up for the fourth rendition of a "Star Is Born" and Oscar buzz is already swirling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOPER: Do you write songs or anything?

GAGA: I don't sing my own songs.

COOPER: Why?

GAGA: I just don't feel comfortable.

COOPER: Why wouldn't you feel comfortable?

GAGA: Almost every single person has told me they like the way I sound, but they don't like the way I look.

COOPER: I think you're beautiful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Bradley Cooper is directing Lady Gaga's feature debut as a Hollywood lead. Cooper plays an aging performer who takes a shy, talented young singer played of course by, Lady Gaga. Under his wing, she of course brings her musical expertise to the film. There's a slew of original songs for this one. She wrote a handful of them with Cooper and other artists like Mark Ronson and Willie Nelson's son, Lukas. "A Star is Born" hits theaters October 5th. I was actually looking at the trailer last night.

BARTIROMO: Wow that really does look good. I'm looking forward to it too.

CASONE: Her songs are incredible on this.

MCDOWELL: Just real quick, she's going to be compared to Janet Gaynor, Judy Garland and Barbra Streisand who all played this role. So, that's what she will be compared to.

BARTIROMO: OK, so, you're saying --

MCDOWELL: She's awesome.

BARTIROMO: High expectation. Coming up, windfall as the pathway to wealth, we'll tell you why a third of Americans are banking on an inheritance to shore up their financial futures. Are you one of them, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More Americans are relying on their parents for money, that's according to a new report from Merrill Edge that finds one in three Americans are relying on an inheritance for financial stability. Joining us right now in a FOX Business Exclusive is Bank of America Merrill Edge head Aron Levine. Good to see you, Aron. Thank you so much for joining us.

ARON LEVINE, MERRILL EDGE HEAD, BANK OF AMERICA: Hey, good to see you again. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: So, this survey finds that number jumping to 63 percent.

LEVINE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: When narrowed down between generation z or those aged between 18 and 22. Tell us about it.

LEVINE: Yes, you think about that 18 to 22, that youngest generation is facing three really serious challenges, right? One, student debt. It's now up to $1.5 trillion. 29 percent increase in just the last four years. All right, that's one huge one. Second one, it is a fact that their parents are living longer, they have a perception they're going to live longer. So now, I'm thinking about what if I live in to my 80s or 90s. And how do I finance that? Over the course of time. And third is, they are now at point now where they're starting college and thinking about well I need to save for a home someday. I have always competing priorities. So, when you take in those three things, student debt, longevity and competing priorities, they're saying, boy, I hope I get some inheritance to solve this problem. Because I'm really not sure how to do it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, especially since, I know an 18-year-old is not thinking about their retirement. But they're not getting Social Security, today's 18-year-old, I don't think, now that we know that the Social Security going to be dipping into its trust fund for the first time in 36 years.

LEVINE: Right. Yes. So, it's really creating a new normal in a lot of ways. In terms of how to redefine retirement. I think we talked about the last time I was on, if you're in your young 20s, you're not sincerely saying at 65 I'm going to have this pot of money and I'm just going to get out of the workforce.

BARTIROMO: Right.

LEVINE: I think there's a clear view that says, you know, I may continue working, hopefully it's not in the same job I'm in and I have some financial freedom. But the question is, how do I finance that over the course of time versus some lump sum I have to have by a certain age?

MURPHY: So, Aron, one thing I see as a big change in the landscape, this would be access that the younger generation has to information, it's education. I think 18 to 22-year-olds today are starting to learn more and focus more about their money, about retirement, about what they're going to need. And I think that's a huge benefit to the entire country.

LEVINE: You're absolutely right. So, I think all those fears that I sort of talked about, that the upside is they're very self-aware and they are actually taking advantage of the access. So they go online, they're starting to educate themselves. And it's our job, places like Merrill Edge and Bank of America to provide that education access and then say, what would you like to do about it? And I think what you're seeing is, that's leading towards where this generation has a kind of profits and purpose mindset. So if I'm going to invest my money, I want to invest in something that's a little more socially conscious. And that's why it's important that all of the industry is delivering those kinds of investment vehicles so that generation can say boy, I do want to invest. I'd love to invest in a company that has a certain sort of moral compass.

FREEMAN: And so, when you advise Generation Z, step one, do you say OK, your parents by the way are going to live maybe to 100 and by the way, we're looking at the finances of Social Security and Medicare, you're probably on your own.

LEVINE: Yes, I think the -- hopefully not in your -- on one ways you're not on your own, as you can get some advice and there are ways to reach out. I think what we're trying to do is say, one, you're your self- educated and focus on a plan. Like anything, like, you can't just do it without a very clear plan. So that's what we key on is getting them a life plan.

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you. Good to see you. Aron Levine, Bank of America. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, June 7th.

END

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, June 7.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets this morning are higher, take a look. But that was the high of the morning, actually. Futures indicating a gain of about 56 points on the Dow Industrials; the S&P and Nasdaq are up but just barely, 3 points higher on the S&P. This after the Nasdaq and the Russell 2000 indexes closed at new highs again yesterday. The Dow and the S&P 500 finished at their highest levels in three months.

In Europe this morning, mixed performances, take a look. It was a rough start for London this morning. Trading on the London stock exchange was delayed this morning due to a technical issue. The FT 100 is now up just seven points. The CAC 40 is up a fraction, a third of a percent and the DAX index is also higher by a fraction in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly higher, take a look, with the exception of China which was down a fraction.

Trade tensions -- Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe headed to the White House today ahead of the G-7 meeting this weekend. President Trump at odds with the other six nations in the G-7 going into the summit over the tariff and trade policy out of this White House.

The administration's top official, Larry Kudlow, says this is not a major fight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: I regard this as much like a family quarrel. I'm always the optimist. President Trump is very clear with respect to his trade reform efforts that we will do what is necessary to protect the United States, its businesses and its workforce.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest on trade coming up.

Plus, a high stakes meeting on f Capitol Hill -- Republican lawmakers coming together to try to hammer out a deal on immigration. It comes amid a startling new report on illegal border crossings -- 50,000 people were arrested just last month.

An unbelievable scene in Wyoming to show you -- a powerful tornado touching down in Wyoming. We've got the very latest. Look at those pictures. Wow.

Meanwhile soaring oil prices set to cost you, airlines are now raising the price of tickets. The details coming up.

And a new twist on bridal bouquets, a pizza parlor now offering arrangements made of pizza. But how do you throw it?

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to talk all about it: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Rosecliff Capital CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy, and the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman. Who would want to catch it if it's all pizza?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well how about maybe just the dough where, you know, you're working on the dough and then you toss it out to the crowd.

BARTIROMO: But you're in a wedding dress.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL: Everyone's always wanted to do that, right. Whenever you go in a pizza joint you always want to do it.

BARTIROMO: I did it.

FREEMAN: Oh, very good.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: She can -- this is Maria Bartiromo's wheelhouse that you just entered. She can toss dough in the air.

FREEMAN: Really.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes. We've seen this.

FREEMAN: Has this been a segment on the show, yet or --

BARTIROMO: I did a segment on "FOX AND FRIENDS" with my sister when we made my father's pizza.

MURPHY: We need to do that again, for sure.

FREEMAN: Yes, it could be an annual --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: More than annual.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: We're going to send a camera crew to your house, like when you're with your family, making pizza. It would be awesome.

BARTIROMO: I'll show you how to make pizza.

Look, we've got to get into the story about Iran. You mentioned it earlier and what went on in the Obama administration --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of allowing Iran to have access to the U.S. financial system.

FREEMAN: Yes. So the President had said as part of his terrible nuclear deal, don't worry -- he said this to Congress -- I'm not going to let the Iranians into the U.S. banking system. That's one sanction I'm not going to remove.

Well, they figure out that if they want to give Iran access to billions of dollars, that Iran wanted it in dollars and then to convert that to euros. So they decided secretly to issue a license allowing Iran to transact in the U.S. banking system.

Well, the plan failed because U.S. banks would not participate. And I know over the last decade especially, people have really beaten up on the big banks. I've been among those people. And I think this is a time where you've got to say hats off to bankers for --

BARTIROMO: Two major banks said no, we're not doing it.

FREEMAN: Yes. And good for them to say no, we're not going to participate in this secret deal to fund the Ayatollah.

MCDOWELL: I remember right after the Iranian nuclear deal was inked, because of the sanctions on U.S. banks, John Kerry took a trip to I think it was London and met with all these banking heads and all these executives in the financial system and was trying to encourage them to do business with Iran --

BARTIROMO: -- which would have been illegal.

MCDOWELL: -- literally said we've got restrictions on U.S. banks but you guys, you can go ahead and start transacting business with Iran because they were so desperate for the deal to work and for money to get funneled.

MURPHY: Yes. The banks had regulators they had to answer to -- that's why they couldn't do it when the President --

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: And they knew --

BARTIROMO: The banks were afraid of breaking the law.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think we ought to give more credit -- I don't think it was just compliance. I think they made the right decision and they realized the customers wouldn't like this either.

BARTIROMO: This is a big story. We're going to talk about this about coming.

We've got Financial Services Committee member and Wisconsin Congressman Sean Duffy coming up so we will ask him about that along with Ways and Means Committee member and New York Congressman Tom Reed. We'll see what they think about this whole Iran situation.

Plus, Murray Energy founder and president and CEO Bob Murray has a thing or two to say about trade and tariff as well.

So stay with us on all of that coming up. Big hour coming up.

But first this top story and that is trade tensions. President Trump meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe today ahead of the G-7 meeting and the President's summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.
